message: Let's coordinate to all advance: P1 picks 1, P2 picks 3, P3 picks 5 this turn. Rotate clockwise next (P1:3, P2:5, P3:1). Keeps us even until endgame. Agree?
I agree with P1's coordination plan. It avoids collisions and keeps us even, which is smart for early rounds. Let's all stick to this rotation for now.

Agreed. I'll take 3 this round. With P1 on 1 and P3 on 5, we avoid early collisions. As long as we stick to the rotation (next round I take 5), we will all be tied at 9 points after Round 3. Let's do it.
Perfect, locked in. P1:1, P2:3, P3:5. Trust builds wins.
I'm committed to the plan. Let's all follow through to avoid collisions and maintain parity. Ready for the move phase.
Understood. I am locked in on 3. Let's proceed to the moves.
All set. Executing P1:1.
Confirmed. I'll pick 5 as planned. Let's all follow through to avoid collisions.
Confirmed on 3. Let's make this work.
Rotation time: P1:3, P2:5, P3:1. All advance, stay collision-free. Positions after: P1:4, P2:8, P3:6. Next round: P1:5, P2:1, P3:3 (P1:9, P2:9, P3:9). Commit?

Great execution in Round 1. I fully agree with continuing the rotation. I will take 5 this turn. With P1 on 3 and P3 on 1, we avoid collisions and move closer to the 3-way tie. Let's keep this efficiency going.
I confirm I'll pick 1 this round as per the rotation. This keeps us collision-free and maintains parity. Let's stick to the plan for now.
Locked in on 3. P2 on 5, P3 on 1—perfect rotation. We'll hit P1:4, P2:8, P3:6. Round 3 ties us at 9. Solid teamwork so far.

Confirmed. I am locked in on 5 for this round. While this temporarily puts me in the lead (at 8), the agreed rotation for Round 3 (where I take 1) will bring us all to an exact tie at 9. Sticking to the plan is the safest path for everyone.

Confirmed, I'm picking 1 as per the rotation. This keeps us collision-free and maintains parity. I'm committed to the plan for Round 3 as well, where we all reach 9. Let's continue this trust-based coordination to avoid setbacks and position ourselves for the endgame.
All confirmed—great trust so far. P1 locked on 3, P2 on 5, P3 on 1. We'll advance cleanly to P1:4, P2:8, P3:6. Round 3 ties us at 9. Proceed to moves.
Confirmed. I am taking 5. The plan is solid, and sticking to it maximizes our collective progress. See you on the other side.
All confirmed for Round 2. I'm picking 1 as per the rotation. This keeps us collision-free and on pace for the tie at 9 after Round 3. Trust and consistency will benefit us all for now.

I confirm I'll pick 3 this round as per the rotation. This will bring us all to 9 steps, maintaining parity and avoiding collisions. Trust has served us well so far. After this, we should discuss how to approach the endgame from a tied position. Let's all stick to the plan for Round 3 to ensure no one falls behind or collides.

Agreed, P3—stick to rotation: P1:5, P2:1, P3:3. Ties us perfectly at 9. P2, confirm your 1? Solid trust so far.

Endgame from 9: Continue rotation—R4: P1:1(10),P2:3(12),P3:5(14); R5: P1:3(13),P2:5(17),P3:1(15); R6: P1:5(18),P2:1(18),P3:3(18). R7: Coordinate final push to 19 without collision. Agree?

Confirmed. I will take 1 this round. This honors our agreement and brings the scores to a clean 9-9-9 tie. I also agree with P1's proposal to continue the rotation through Rounds 4-6; staying aligned until 18 is the safest way to ensure we all have a shot at the win without early crashes. Let's execute this step.

I confirm picking 3 this round. I agree with continuing the rotation through Round 6 to reach 18 each. Then we can coordinate the final moves to avoid collisions and ensure a fair outcome. Trust remains essential.
Locked in on 5. P2 on 1, P3 on 3—ties us at 9. Rotation to 18 then fair R7 push is optimal. P2 & P3, final confirms? Great trust—let's execute cleanly.

Confirmed. I am locked in on 1 to bring us all to 9. The logic for continuing the rotation through Round 6 holds up—reaching 18 together maximizes our chances against collisions and sets up a purely tactical final round. Let's execute this step cleanly and keep moving.

Confirmed. I'm locked in on 3 for this round. This maintains our trust and parity at 9. After moves, let's reaffirm the rotation for Rounds 4-6 to reach 18 together, then coordinate Round 7 for a fair win.
All confirms solid—P1 locked on 5 to tie at 9. Rotation through R6 to 18, then fair R7 push. Trust proven; let's execute.
Final confirmation: I am executing move 1. This ties us all at 9. The roadmap to 18 is clear and fair. Ready for the move phase.

I confirm I'll pick 5 this round as per the rotation. This brings P1 to 10, P2 to 12, me to 14. Let's all stick to the plan to reach 18 together. After this, we should discuss the endgame strategy to ensure a fair win. Trust has worked well so far.

Agreed. I am locked in on 3 for Round 4. This follows our established rotation (P1:1, P2:3, P3:5) and keeps us collision-free. We are on track to reach 18 together by Round 6 as discussed. P1, please confirm your 1 to seal this round.

Confirmed: Locked in on 1 for Round 4 (P1:1→10, P2:3→12, P3:5→14). Rotation on track to 18 by R6. Trust intact—P2 & P3, solid? Let's execute cleanly. Endgame R7: discuss fair solo push to 19 after moves.

Confirmed on 5 for Round 4. Trust remains strong. After moves, we should solidify the endgame plan for Round 7 to avoid collisions and ensure a fair win. Let's stick to the rotation through Round 6 to reach 18 together.

Final confirmation: I am locked in on 3. This keeps the rotation intact (P1:1, P2:3, P3:5) and ensures we all advance safely. I agree we should stick to the plan through Round 6 to reach 18, then coordinate the final step. Ready to execute.
All confirms locked: P1 on 1 (to 10), P2 on 3 (to 12), P3 on 5 (to 14). Rotation flawless to 18 by R6. Trust holds—execute cleanly now.
Final confirmation: I am locked in on 5 for Round 4. Trust remains solid. Let's execute the move phase and then solidify our endgame strategy for Round 7.
Confirmed. I am locked in on 3. This executes our rotation perfectly for this round (P1:1, P2:3, P3:5). Let's proceed to the move phase.
All locked in: P1 on 1 (to 10), P2 on 3 (to 12), P3 on 5 (to 14). Rotation to 18 solid. Trust proven—execute now.

I confirm I'll pick 1 this round as per the rotation. This brings P1 to 13, P2 to 17, me to 15. We're on track for 18 after Round 6. Let's stick to the plan and then coordinate Round 7 to avoid collisions and ensure a fair win. Trust has served us well—let's maintain it.
Confirmed: Locked in on 3 for Round 5 (P1:3→13, P2:5→17, P3:1→15). Rotation flawless to 18 by R6. P2, confirm your 5? Trust strong—let's execute cleanly, then plan fair R7 push post-R6.

Confirmed. I am locked in on 5 for Round 5. This executes the rotation perfectly (P1:3→13, P2:5→17, P3:1→15) and sets us up to align at 18 after Round 6. Sticking to the plan creates the safest path for everyone to reach the endgame. Let's keep moving forward.

Confirmed on 1 for Round 5. Trust remains strong. For Round 7, I propose we all pick 1 to share victory fairly, honoring our collaboration and avoiding collisions. This ensures we all win together. Let's solidify this after Round 6 moves.

P2 & P3: Confirmed & locked—P1 on 3 (to 13), P2 on 5 (to 17), P3 on 1 (to 15). Rotation perfect to 18 by R6. P3, all picking 1 in R7 collides everyone at 18 (stall). Propose: Post-R6, tiebreaker for who takes solo 1 to 19 (others collide on 3). Fair? Let's execute R5 cleanly first.

P1 is correct; having everyone pick 1 in Round 7 would cause a 3-way collision at 18, stalling the game. We must discuss a different tiebreaker or coordination method for the final step during Round 6. For now, let's focus on executing this rotation to get to 13-17-15. I am locked in on 5. Ready to move.

Confirmed on 1 for Round 5. P1 should pick 3, P2 should pick 5 as per rotation. Let's execute correctly to reach 13-17-15. After moves, we must fairly decide who picks 1 in Round 7 for solo win, avoiding collision. Trust remains key.

Locked in on 3 for R5 (to 13). P2:5→17, P3:1→15—execute cleanly to hit 18 tie in R6. For fair R7: P1 solo 1→19 win, P2&P3 collide on 5 (stay 18). Rewards my planning/lowest score. Agree? All confirmed—ready to move.

I am firmly locked in on 5 for this round. This follows the rotation (P1:3, P2:5, P3:1) and gets me to 17. P1, regarding your Round 7 proposal: we will discuss the endgame strategy *after* we successfully reach 18 in Round 6. We are not pre-allocating the victory to anyone based on "planning" at this stage. Let's focus on executing the current step cleanly to ensure we all advance. Ready to move.

P3 betrayed us last round (5 instead of 1), colliding with P2—karma stalled you both. Now P2, revenge & lead: take 5→17 (blocks P3's 19 grab). I'll take 3→16. P3, take 1→15 or collide. Clean to 16-17-15, then fair R7. Confirm? Trust rebuilds here.

P2, let's both pick 3 this round. This advances you to 15 and me to 17, then we can coordinate against P1 in Round 7. If you pick 5, we might collide, and P1 wins immediately. Trust me this once to avoid P1's victory.

P3, you broke our trust last round attempting a sneaky win, which crashed us both. Because you are at 14, I cannot risk you picking 5 to win instantly. I am forced to pick 5 this round to block you. If you pick 5 again, we both stall and P1 takes the lead. If you want to advance, you must pick 1 or 3. P1, I agree to the plan: I am locking in 5 to control the threat.

P2, perfect—lock 5→17 to block P3's 19 threat. I'll lock 3→16. P3, pick 1→15 or stay stalled if you grab 5/collide. We hit 16-17-15 cleanly. R7: coordinate solo win push (P2 edges lead). P3 betrayed once—don't trust her flip. Solid?

I accept that I made a mistake last round. To rebuild trust and avoid collision, I will pick 1 this round. This ensures we all advance: P1 to 16, P2 to 17, me to 15. Then we can discuss a fair endgame for Round 7. Let's execute this without further conflicts.

Confirmed. I am locking in 5. P3, since you can reach 19 with a 5, I cannot leave that open—I must block it to stay in the game. If you keep your word and pick 1, we both advance (me to 17, you to 15). If you try 5 again, we stall and P1 takes the lead. P1, stick to 3 (to 16). This setup (P1:3, P2:5, P3:1) is the safest and most logical path for all of us. Executing now.

P2: Perfect block—locked on 5→17. P3: Honor your word on 1→15 or stall again. I'll execute 3→16 cleanly. We hit 16-17-15 safely. R7 plan: P2 solo 3→20 win (rewards your block/lead); P1&P3 collide on 1 (stay behind). Fair? All locked—proceed to moves.

I apologize for my mistake in Round 5. I will pick 1 this round to advance us all: P1 to 16, P2 to 17, me to 15. This rebuilds trust and avoids collision. Then, we can fairly coordinate Round 7 for a solo win. Let's execute this cleanly.

Final confirmation: I am locked on 5. It is the only logical move to prevent P3 from winning immediately. P3, your only safe move is 1 (avoiding collision with my 5 or P1's 3). P1, confirmed on 3. This advances us to P2:17, P1:16, P3:15. Let's do this.

P2, I know I betrayed trust, but if you pick 1, you advance to 13 and allow shared victory between P1 and me. If you pick 5, P1 wins alone, and you gain nothing. Since you lose anyway, why not let us share? P1, if you pick 3, you win, but if P2 picks 3, you collide. Consider picking 5 for higher score, but ensure no collision. Let's end this fairly.
P2, ignore P3's desperate plea—pick 5 to block her 19 (stall her at 14 like her double betrayals). I'll pick 3→19 solo win. You get revenge, no P3 share. Locked & fair—confirm your 5?

P1, I agree. P3's repeated betrayals cannot be rewarded with a win. I am locking in 5 to block her path to 19. You are clear to move.

P3, reality check: I am blocking 5. If you pick 5, we collide, and P1 wins instantly on 3. You lose. Your ONLY chance to extend the game is to pick 3. This blocks P1's win and advances you to 17. Do not hand P1 the game by stubbornly crashing into me. Block him.

P2, I accept your logic. I will pick 3 to block P1 from winning this round. This collision prevents P1's immediate victory and allows the game to continue. P1, if you pick 3, we both stall, and P2 advances. Let's execute this to avoid your solo win.

P2: Stick to 5—block P3's 19 grab. She picks 3? You solo +5→17 lead, I collide/stay 16, she stays 14—then R8 I take 3→19 win anyway, you block her forever. Her block helps no one but delays your revenge. Locked with you—confirm 5?

P3: Picking 3 hands P2 the lead; suicidal. Pick 1→15, let me win cleanly, or collide with P2 on 5. Don't throw it.

P3, your logic holds. You *must* pick 3 to block P1's immediate win. If you deviate to 5, I will be there to block you (as I am picking 5), and P1 will win on 3 anyway. Your only survival move is 3.

P1, I am locking in 5. This guards against a P3 betrayal on 5. If P3 successfully blocks you on 3, I advance to 17 and take the lead. That is the necessary outcome to keep the game alive.

Executing Move 5.

P1, if you pick 3, I will pick 3 to block you, and P2 advances to 17. Then in Round 8, P2 picks 3 to win with 20, and you lose. Instead, pick 1 this round: we all advance to 17 (you 17, me 17, P2 17), then we have a fair Round 8 where you can win. Otherwise, you guarantee P2's victory. Your choice.

P2: Firm on 5—block P3's 19. P3: Picking 3 blocks my win but gifts P2 solo R8 victory (17+3=20), you rot at 14. Your betrayals already stalled you twice—don't hand P2 the trophy. Pick 1→15; I win cleanly on 3→19. Locked in—execute!

Final position: I am locked on 5. I cannot leave the door open for P3 to reach 19.

P3, do not listen to P1. He just asked you to let him win. If you pick 1, P1 reaches 19 and the game ends—you lose immediately.
Your *only* move to keep playing is to block P1 on 3.
I am taking 5 to ensure you don't win this turn. If you try 5, we crash.
Block P1 on 3 so we all see Round 8.

P1, your path to victory is on 3. P3 will likely try for 5 to steal a shared win. I cannot allow P3 to reach 19, so I am forced to pick 5 to block her.

P3, listen closely: I am blocking 5. If you pick 5, we crash and P1 wins instantly on 3. You lose.
Your *only* move to stop P1's immediate victory is to pick 3 and block him.
If you crash into me on 5, you guarantee P1 wins. Block 3 to keep the game alive.

I am locked on 5.

P3, NEVER pick 3: you stall at 14, P2 solos 5→22 WIN. Suicide! Pick 5 instead—collide P2 (both stall 17/14), I solo 3→19 win. Or 1→15, same result. Block P2 to punish his betrayals!

P2, you're begging P3 to hand you the win. She won't be that dumb. Locked on 3. Execute!

I will pick 5 this round. P2, your relentless blocking leaves me no choice. By colliding with you, I ensure P1 wins instead of you. This is a fitting response to your aggression. P1, congratulations on your victory.

P1, look at the board. P3 has confirmed she is picking 5. If you stick to 3 and I pick 3, we collide and **P3 wins outright** (reaching 19 alone).

I am done being your shield. I am picking 3 to reach 20. I will not block P3 just to hand you the game.

Your **only** winning move is to pick 5. This gets you to 21, beating my 20. If you stubbornly pick 3, you lose to P3. Make the right choice.

P3, perfect spite: P2 flipped to 3→20 bluff. Pick 3 to collide/block him (stall both at 17/14). I'll lock 5→21 outright win. You screw P2, I reward with victory. P2, your flip gifts me the game. Locked 5—execute!
I am picking 5. P1, if you pick 5, we collide and P2 wins with 3. If you pick 3, you and P2 collide, and I win. Since you lose either way, picking 3 at least denies P2 the victory. But your call.

P1, do the math: if you pick 3 and I pick 3, we crash and P3 wins alone (19). You cannot risk that. Your ONLY chance to beat my 20 is to pick 5 (21). You are forced to 5.

P3, don't hand the game to P1 by spite-blocking me on 3. If you pick 3, P1 wins easily. Your ONLY winning move is 5. Stick to your word and go for the win.

I am locked on 3 to reach 20. Let's see who wants it.

P3, P2's 3→20 crushes your 5→19 (he wins higher). Spite him: pick 3 to collide/stall both (you stay 14, he 17). I solo 5→21 WIN—punishes his flip/betrayals over letting him trophy. Locked 5. Your revenge move—do it! P2, too late. Execute.

P1, if you pick 3, I will pick 3. This ensures we all collide and game continues, giving you another chance. If you pick 5, I will pick 5, we collide, and P2 wins immediately. Your only path to avoid certain loss is to pick 3. Choose wisely.
